New Records: Pete Alonso became the first player in MLB history to hit a go-ahead home run with his team trailing in the ninth inning or later in a winner-take-all playoff game.
Key Match Events: Pete Alonso hit a three-run home run in the top of the ninth inning as the New York Mets worked their comeback magic in a 4-2 victory over the Milwaukee Brewers to advance in the MLB playoffs.
The Mets trailed 2-0 after Milwaukee's Jake Bauers and Sal Frelick belted back-to-back homers in the bottom of the seventh to break open a scoreless game.
The Mets finally broke through against Brewers closer Devin Williams, who walked Francisco Lindor to open the ninth.
The Mets added one more run after Jesse Winker was hit by a pitch from Williams, stole second base and scored on a single by Starling Marte.
Post-Match Reflections: Pete Alonso said, "I was just looking out over the middle of the plate, just looking to hit something hard forward. Man, this is something that you practice in the backyard as a kid. I'm just happy to come through for the boys."

Alonso added, "I had some great at-bats in front of me. I'm really happy I got to come through for the team right there. We've worked so hard all year to get to this point. I'm just so happy I was able to contribute."
Miscellaneous Highlights: The Mets advanced in the MLB playoffs with a 4-2 victory over the Milwaukee Brewers.

The victory gave the Mets a 2-1 triumph in the best-of-three National League Wild Card series and sends them into a best-of-five second-round clash with the Philadelphia Phillies starting on Saturday.
